summary: In this anime feature, 13-year-old Kiki moves to a seaside town with her talking cat, Jiji, to spend a year alone, in accordance with her village's tradition for witches in training. After learning to control her broomstick, Kiki sets up a flying courier service and soon becomes a fixture in the community. But when the insecure young witch begins questioning herself and loses her magic abilities, she must overcome her self-doubt to get her powers back.

reviews.content: This movie is so awesome, and even though I like cats

Kiki's Delivery Service is studio Ghibli at its peak with a wonderful aesthetic, great music, fantastic animation, and a plot you can't forget. This coming of age story centers around Kiki, a young apprentice witch who is setting out on her own for the first time with her talking cat, Jiji, in an effort to find herself.

This is my favorite film of all time. I would write a longer review but I could not put the love I have for his film into words. Every character is so likable, the themes are incredible and it has actively effected my life at times. This is truest a must see

Like I said with Nausicaa, Kiki's Delivery Service for me isn't quite a top 5 of my favourite Ghibli movies, it makes for a solid position in my top 10. It is a beautiful film, light-hearted and entertaining with very little to criticise really. The story is simple yet very imaginative, the dialogue is good and the pacing is well judged. My favourite assets of Kiki's Delivery Service are the animation, music and characters. The animation as you would expect is gorgeous especially in the colours, and the music is stunning. The characters are unique, likable and always engaging, I have to say Kiki is one of my favourite protagonists ever in a Ghibli movie and I mean that. Overall, lovely and delightful. 9.5/10 Bethany Cox

This movie surprised me because how much I liked it. You may be able to tell that I am more attracted to the films with darker tones and harder hitting messages, but there is so much personality with this story that kept my attention. Kiki is a very lovable character and throughout the film you are really rooting for her to succeed especially when she loses her confidence. She isn't out to fight some big evil villain, but just fighting to find her purpose life. It may sound like a simple story, but there are many parts of this that make it more complex and engaging than what you may expect. You have Jiji, her cat that is voiced by the always wonderful Phil Hartman. He is one of those people you love seeing on screen whether he is good, bad, or in between. Tombo is reflective of Miazaki's child-like wonder of aviation you feel encouraged seeing him pursuing his dream alongside Kiki. Osono is a very sweet and motherly parental figure for Kiki on her life away from home. Ursula serves as a great role model for Kiki and is there to support her in her time of need. All the supporting cast carries a great heart and charm about them, and it makes it into a very pleasant feeling film. The message about the power of self-confidence really carries itself through the entire story without forcing a heavy-handed choice at the end. It really shows how much you can have done when you believe in yourself and have really supportive friends around you.

"| Ratings Categories |
{Characters (7/10) ; Cinematography (9.5/10) ; Plot (7.5/10) ; Acting (7.5/10) ; Pacing (7.5/10) = 78%}"

As an original animated movie from Miyazaki that immerses the audience into the magical world of teenage independence, it surprisingly doesn't focus much on the fantasy elements as one would think. The highlight is Kiki (a 13-year-old girl who just happens to be a witch with a broom), and her experience getting a job in a strange new place while on the path to becoming an independent witch. Not only are the characters written well and play significant roles in helping to build Kiki as a person, the world around them is expertly constructed to support the narrative. Another Ghibli masterpiece that serves to remind audiences that Anime isn't just about fan service. 9.5/10

Kiki's Delivery Service is the best Ghibli film, meet me out behind the dumpsters if you want to fight.

Part of what makes Kiki's Delivery Service so great is its sense of restraint. Yes, Kiki is a witch and her ability to fly (a common motif in Ghibli films, particularly those in which Miyazaki had a hand in creating) grants us some incredible sweeping visuals, but witches are shown to be relatively familiar in this world; a curiosity, but not unheard of. So while you get to be whisked away by the charm and whimsy of the premise and animation quality, you have this amazingly down to earth protagonist whose struggles are eminently relatable - growing up, maturing, finding a sense of self and exploring while remaining vulnerable. While there are certainly bumps along the way, her journey introduces her to a number of interesting characters, many of which become close friends. Though there is a sense of safety inherent to a world this good-natured, Miyazaki doesn't forget about the bit of loss involved with groing up; when Kiki regains her powers, it's a triumphant and grand moment, but tinged with sadness as she realizes that she still can't communicate with her cat, Jiji. It's a necessary evolution, but there is still some bit of melancholy in it (but then you see that fantastic end credits sequence with Jiji's adorable kittens, and even a younger girl wearing Kiki's outfit, just to make sure you don't walk away legitimately sad).

A brief note, one thing that Ghibli has always done incredibly well is character design, from physical attributes to mannerisms. And it's not limited to major characters, here some of the most endearing and charming individuals are the supporting roles, who convey so much nonverbally or through their reactions, such as the dog Jeff and particularly the daydreaming and excitable maid. Gosh, the details are good.

Rewatched at Ghiblifest 2022. (5/5)
Wonderful and lighthearted film, a coming of age story about finding your place in the world and yourself.
as a children's action movie...Emily's favorite movie. she's a witch with a talking cat.

Like I said with Nausicaa, Kiki's Delivery Service for me isn't quite a top 5 of my favourite Ghibli movies, it makes for a solid position in my top 10. It is a beautiful film, light-hearted and entertaining with very little to criticise really. The story is simple yet very imaginative, the dialogue is good and the pacing is well judged. My favourite assets of Kiki's Delivery Service are the animation, music and characters. The animation as you would expect is gorgeous especially in the colours, and the music is stunning. The characters are unique, likable and always engaging, I have to say Kiki is one of my favourite protagonists ever in a Ghibli movie and I mean that. Overall, lovely and delightful. 9.5/10 Bethany Cox
Not among my favorite Ghibli films, but good for kids.

I liked this one more than Totoro. I found the story to be very relatable and I liked a lot of the filmmaking decisions they made, like the impeccable blending of the exposition into the rising action in the first few minutes; they explained the premise and got the show started quickly without the use of a narrator or similar crutch. There was some boomer-esque criticism of the younger generation sprinkled in and I didn't like how insincere she was with her apologies (her dad had prolly been planning that camping trip for weeks) but those were relatively unobtrusive problems in what was otherwise a very enjoyable viewing experience. The Hindenburg re-enactment was awesome!
my FAVORITE studio ghibli movie !! loved every minute of it ! go watch it RN !!

Confidence, lovable Kiki and her spicy black cat Jiji set out to an adorable seaside town for Kiki's delivery service. With its merry tone and unforgettable characters, this film is a must for families.

Kiki's Delivery Service is a lighthearted, simplistic, and engaging story for both young and old audiences, with lessons about venturing out into the world to build a career for yourself and burning out of your passion, told from the perspective of a 13-year-old. The animation and story are both quite pleasant, and our main protagonist Kiki (Minami Takayama) is a joy to see on screen, as are the supporting characters in this film. Kiki's Delivery Service "delivers" exactly what it promises.
It's the sudden death itself. 1/10

Kiki's Delivery Service is a really good film with character development. The landscapes are gorgeous. It has witches, a sassy cat, and an airship. I like how Kiki had challenges and eventually overcame them. Overall, the animation style is amazing as usual.
It was a fantastic movie! Great coming of age story!
Fantastic. Great for kids and adults. Recommend!
top 3 best movies from studio ghibli
This anime was made in 1989 and still captivates me every time I watch it. A must-watch feel-good movie with a beautiful story.

Cute, heartwarming, beautifully scored and animated, this gem is one of the earliest crownings achievements of Ghibli Studio... It may sound and appear childish for the public in general, but if you look and pay attetion to minimum details, you can see a very original coming of age story in this picture.
Wonderfully animated, good-natured tale of a young girl making her way in life on her own; full of memorable and exciting moments.

adventure, magic, halloween vibes, teen angst, puppy love. its all the good things. i loved the friendship btw kiki and gigi. i loved the plot twists. such good characters. all the feels with this one-sad, happy, laughter. the only thing wasn't crazy about is how she nevers writes to her parents until like a year later and the fact that she goes to travel the world at 13-ridic.
this whole movie is just incredible, i watched it 3 time and it is just so amazing, everyone must watch the anime

A delightful piece that proves that even when you have at hand a story about a teenage girl with special powers who must leave her home and discover the wide world, you don't necessary need to rise stakes, create villains, introduce schools for gifted youngsters and, in the and, make it all about saving the world. No, you can instead turn it into calm, warm, enchanting slice of life coming of age story with lots of small, inconsequential events. You can then tell a story that is all about characters and the bonds between them, not really though about the adventures they have themselves. The focus of "Kiki's Delivery Service" lies it the life itself – the life of this young girl and how she experiences it. In a sense, it is an anti-"young adult media" piece that rejected the many downfalls of "Harry Potter" copies and anime for teenagers even before they grew in popularity as a genre. This is what makes it beautiful and so, so refreshing even today, thirty years later.

"Kiki's Delivery Service" is among Studio Ghibli's more lighthearted and kid-friendly outings, but it is just as charming and imaginative as any other movie from the studio. This movie has a simple enough premise but it is handled in creative ways and is a joy to watch. The story didn't do too much for me, but I thought it led up to a very engaging final act. I also thought the subtle themes about growing up and finding your independence were aspects most adults can relate to. All in all, I would say out of the Ghibli films I have seen so far, this is a solid one, not among my favorites, but certainly not among my least favorites, and it's one I think a wide range of audiences can enjoy together.

Possibly my favourite Ghibli release to date, this follows 13-year-old Kiki as she moves to a seaside town with her talking cat, Jiji, to spend a year alone, in accordance with her village's tradition for witches in training. After learning to control her broomstick, Kiki sets up a flying courier service and soon becomes a fixture in the community, and what I enjoyed so much about this is that is just a genuinely happy and uplifting movie without any sort of real peril. My 2 year old enjoyed it immensely (apart from not being able to read the subtitles) and the visual representation of what, to me, looked like an old European town is absolutely stunning. A real treat.

Miyazaki's films are so effortless, so pure. Yet so simple, so magical, so true. To me, Miyazaki is the Da Vinci of animation. 

Looking for plot description? Google it, mate!
Enjoyed this movie. This movie is very relaxing.
Another win for Miyazaki! Set in a different world than most of his other films, this was still a very fun and enjoyable film. Not my favorite Studio Ghibli, but still enjoyable!
A feel good film with the classic animation style that works so well

Sheesh, this movie is just so darn lovable. Even though it is not heavily plot driven, it more than makes up for it with beautiful aesthetics, interesting characters, and snappy pacing. The simplest things, like Kiki recovering a missing toy from the forest, have the tension and drama that demand your attention from start to finish. 

While Kiki's Delivery Services focuses on the micro, it says a lot about the macro, too. It has a running commentary on the gig economy and burn out. The symbolism of the wind and the zeppelin serve to underscore those elements. If you're interested in learning more about these topics, I'd strongly recommend this video from Patrick H Willems, who is making some of the best content on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KfB69eDCbOI&t=663s

Omg, I can't believe I've seen this movie before and remembered nothing! Just watched it again this month and absolutely fell in love! (I love all things witches, and Kirsten Dunst as Kiki was a perfect casting choice!)
Kiki’s Delivery Service is another heartwarming tale from great director Hayo Miyazaki that is also lighthearted and very touching.

Now we have a typical witch with a broom and a black cat. A story about a young witch moving into a new busy town where she learned responsibility and overcame her self-doubts. The story was very sweet and had me smiling many times. Similarly to Totoro, most of the time I was enjoying the scenes and how the characters explored the new environment. The end sequence was unexpectedly intense, and I was very happy of how it turned out even though I already expected it. My only problem was the theme was not as clear and didn't hit much. Still, had a very enjoyable time with this movie throughout. 8/10

Reviewed 2.4.21  So I'm going to say it....art students and hipsters, cover your ears:  Miyasaki is overrated.  Blasphemy, I know.  But understand, I too am a fan.  He, and his team of animators at Studio Ghibli, have been churning out the creme de le creme of hand drawn animation since he co-founded the studio in 1985.  They were (now with new competition from Cartoon Saloon) the pinnacle of animated film beauty for over 30 years.  This is indisputable fact, and their contribution to the genre can not be overstated.  
That said, movies are more than eye candy.  Truly great movies require captivating stories, which is Miyasaki's Achilles' heel.  And Kiki's Delivery Service is a classic example.  "It's whimsical," his supporters will claim.  But 100+ minutes of whimsy is not in itself a story.  
The idea of a 13-year old witch that uses her flying ability to deliver goods is indeed a fun concept.  And her coming-of-age experiences provide some point to the proceedings.  But one can't deny that the writing could be tighter, and more substantial.
As always with Miyasaki, it's absolutely beautiful to look at, inspiring even.  The animation earns five stars.  But in this case, one wishes the story matched his superior creative skills. PS: In all fairness, my 6 & 4 year old think it's great.  But my review is intended for 'grown ups.'

Although we see some great animation and an excellent setting, this film gets held back with some lackluster technical qualities. The video editing ruined the flow of the movie on multiple occasions and there weren't more than three or four camera-shooting techniques used on a regular basis (which gets tiresome). The audio editing was mostly good (especially during the biggest obstacle for the main character) and the decision to show scenes of the denouement behind the end credits was a nice touch and reminiscent of Taxi Driver. Overall, the premise of creating a Low Fantasy about a witch that struggles to find her way in a world of non-magic folk was a very well-executed idea, even with the film's flaws on lack of spunking the same level of intrigue as other Studio Ghibli or Hayao Miyazaki films. 

Final Rating: Solid to Great 8
Loved this movie as a kid, the first anime movie I've seen.

My first thought about the movie is that it’s so heartwarming and adorable. The movie has little in the way of external conflict, but Kiki deals with internal struggles such as self doubt, loneliness, and vulnerability. The movie handles these themes, and others including the transition from childhood to adulthood and ideas of traditionalism Vs modernism, in a mature and well-written way. The movie’s animation has aged a little, but in a charming way that adds to the tone and look of the movie. I highly recommend the movie if you’re looking for a cute, wholesome movie that has some depth and substance to it.

Hayao Miyazaki's love of flying is taken to new heights with a witch's broom!

Hayao Miyazaki's coming of age drama fantasy anime Kiki's Delivery Service (1989) is an adorably breezy film and one of his finest features. Eiko Kadono's story about a teenage witch going out on her own is very quaint and relatable. It's easily one of my absolute favorite Miyazaki features from Studio Ghibli. You just have to see Kiki's Delivery Service!

Miyazaki's writing lets you empathize with Kiki naturally. Miyazaki dives inside the mind, heart, and feminine perspective of a young girl growing up with dreams of being a witch. She's so relatable and sweet. I think Kiki is one of Miyazaki's best characters and a gentle heroine in her own right. Her bravery comes from the simple courage to go out on her own and forge her own career staying true to her witch self. I'm sure all girls and boys will relate to her melancholy and uncertainty as Kiki learns to believe in herself and find her own inspiration. I also adore how Kiki remains kind despite her depression and unconfidence for a touching lesson in morality.

Miyazaki's direction is fantastic as he gives Kiki's Delivery Service this chill pace and cheerful atmosphere. Kiki's Delivery Service displays Miyazaki's love of flying with brilliant blue skies, a flying witch's broom, a dirigible, and even a propeller bicycle. You feel like soaring with Kiki on her broom as she delivers packages for townsfolk. His direction is always bright and focused as you go on an emotional odyssey with Kiki going on dates, training to be a witch, and making friends like any girl wishes for in her youth. Kiki's Delivery Service is perhaps the most adorable and endearing anime film of Miyazaki's with low stakes conflicts for an ever loving anime picture.

Kirsten Dunst is the perfect voice actress for Kiki in The English Dub of Kiki's Delivery Service. Her sincere caring vocal performance is radiant. Dunst ensures that Kiki is endearing and relatable. Her soft, cute voice finds a playful whimsy, yet heartfelt blend that just works for Kiki. Kirsten Dunst is my favorite actress of all time, so it was wonderful for me to hear here as Kiki's spirited voice.

Janeane Garofalo is phenomenally down to Earth as the sweet lady friend of Kiki's named Ursula. Her natural exuberance is infinitely charming and pairs nicely with Dunst's quirky Kiki. Debbie Reynolds' voice for Madame sounds so gentle with an earnest kindness to it that fits Madame's nice treatment of Kiki. Tress MacNeille voices the bubbly Osono who takes Kiki in at her bakery as a delivery girl. Lastly, may Phil Hartman rest in peace, who delightfully voices Kiki's snarky cat Jiji. He captures Jiji's restless nature and hesitancy at anything new or uncomfortable that Kiki wants to try spontaneously. 

Takeshi Seyama's editing is very relaxed as he allows shots to linger on the cute encounters and beautiful imagery of Studio Ghibli's lovingly hand drawn animation. Seyama's cuts and Miyazaki's direction keep Kiki flying by like a Summer breeze for a cool 103 minutes. Kiki's animation is breathtakingly stunning, vibrantly colorful, and vividly realized with realistic fluidity in their motions. Shigeo Sugimura's striking cinematography is stuffed with pretty far wide shots during Kiki's broom flights and engaging close-ups of Kiki's expressive face. Kiki's enchanting design is adorable and her winning personality is ever endearing. Kiki really is a darling witch from the mind of Miyazaki.

Hinoshi Ono's production design makes the town appear quaint and detailed with a charming warmth, while his art direction looks resplendent in all the open skies of blue and large cobblestone streets. Yoshifumi Kondou's visual effects are particularly lovely whenever Kiki takes off. I found Kiki using a street sweeper's broom to take off with a swirling gust of wind especially dear. Joe Hisaishi's score is as charmingly delightful with playful melodies and serene passages throughout Kiki's Delivery Service. His music provides an air of romance, sense of adventure, feeling of discovery, and endless dreamy atmosphere to Kiki's Delivery Service. His steadfast compositions are always a highlight within Hayao Miyazaki's iconic anime films.

In all, Hayao Miyazaki's anime movie Kiki's Delivery Service is a pure joy to watch. It's peaceful tone is always pleasant. Kiki's Delivery Service is an easy recommendation to all viewers.

Now, this is a movie, Myazaki balances every element with such precision that you forget it's even supposed to be a kid's movie, escapism is probably the most underrated quality of cinema, and I can see why, but when it's elevated to this beauty it becomes the purpose of this art.

Kiki's Delivery Service is on the happier and cuter side of Miyazaki's films. It is an enjoyable movie about a girl finding her place in the world and making friends along the way. It is perfect for adults and kids alike. I really enjoyable movie!

Light, warm and fuzzy, but also at times melancholic, and poignant. Kiki's Delivery Service is a delightful escape into a mesmerising and beautifully illustrated world, and its manifestation in the eyes of a little girl with big dreams. But what is profound about this feature is its devout emphasis on kindness, with Miyazaki subtly elucidating the too-often-forgotten positive influence that each of us can have on one another —- a fable that is evermore resonant in times such as these.
Iroh's grade: B+
I thought I had my favorite movie of all time picked, but this movie made me instantly want to rewatch it.

what else can be said about Miyazaki's wonderful Ghibli films? Stylish and stunning without sacrificing one bit for the storyline (which will warm your heart by the way) Of course if you are a fan of anime films this is a must see, or if you are looking to see what all the hype is about this isn't a bad place to start at all
